Yes, really.ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’» In .NET, using "Microsoft.FeatureManagement" makes this super easy.Hereâ€™s a quick example:if (await featureManager.IsEnabledAsync(FeatureFlags.ClipArticleContent)){ article.Content = article.Content.Substring(0, 50);}âœ… Flag ON? Or wished you could test a feature in production â€” but only for a few users?Thatâ€™s exactly where Feature Flags shine! They let you turn parts of your code ON or OFF at runtime, without deploying new code. Yes, really.ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’» In .NET, using "Microsoft.FeatureManagement" makes this super easy.Hereâ€™s a quick example:if (await featureManager.IsEnabledAsync(FeatureFlags.ClipArticleContent)){ article.Content = article.Content.Substring(0, 50);}âœ… Flag ON? Turns out â€˜Weâ€™ll send it soonâ€™ isnâ€™t legally binding. Who knew?One career mistake I made was working for organizations that never issued offer letters. At the time, I was eager to build my portfolio and gain experience, so I overlooked the importance of formal agreements. Unfortunately, it led to unclear expectations, lack of job security, and even situations where "multitasking" plus one's original job became the norm.I thought,Â â€œAs long as the work is good, everything else will fall into place.â€Â Well, it didnâ€™t.The experience taught me a vital lesson:Â Professionalism starts with structure. Today, I prioritize clarity and mutual respect in any working relationship. If a company canâ€™t provide a basic offer letter, itâ€™s a red flagâ€”not an opportunity and that is on period.To others:Â Have you had a similar experience or learned a tough lesson early in your career? Iâ€™d love to hear your story.hashtag#DigitalMarketing hashtag#SocialMediaManager hashtag#EntrepreneurJourney hashtag#BrandGrowth hashtag#KendygitalMedia hashtag#StorytellingForBrands hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#ProfessionalDevelopmenthashtag#BlessingIyareLinkedInChallenge hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#ProfessionalDevelopment hashtag#30DayChallengeDay 4 of hashtag#BlessingIyareLinkedInChallenge

âœ… "Feature Flags in .NET â€“ Control Your Releases Smarter"ğŸš€ Ever released a new featureâ€¦ only to immediately roll it back due to unexpected issues? Or wished you could test a feature in production â€” but only for a few users?Thatâ€™s exactly where Feature Flags shine! They let you turn parts of your code ON or OFF at runtime, without deploying new code. Yes, really.ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’» In .NET, using "Microsoft.FeatureManagement" makes this super easy.Hereâ€™s a quick example:if (await featureManager.IsEnabledAsync(FeatureFlags.ClipArticleContent)){ article.Content = article.Content.Substring(0, 50);}âœ… Flag ON? Clip content.âŒ Flag OFF? Return full content.ğŸ” All runtime controlled â€” no redeploys!ğŸ’¡ Use cases:*Gradual rollouts (10% of users â†’ 100%)*Kill switches for unstable features*A/B testing*Ops-controlled togglesBut hereâ€™s the catch ğŸ‘‰ Adding flags is easy. Cleaning them up later is crucial. Otherwise, your codebase becomes a flag graveyard. â˜ ï¸ğŸ¨ Image Idea to explain this example of code  visaully : User â†’ API â†’ FeatureManager  | [Flag ON] â€” Shorten content [Flag OFF] â€” Return full contentâš™ï¸ How It Works:1-Check the Feature Flag: The application checks if a specific feature flag is enabled using the FeatureManager.2-Flag Disabled ("No"): If the flag is off, the app executes the fallback logic (e.g., reverting to a previous version of functionality).3-Flag Enabled ("Yes"): If the flag is on, the app proceeds with the new feature or functionality.ğŸ’¬Have you used feature flags in your apps? Turns out â€˜Weâ€™ll send it soonâ€™ isnâ€™t legally binding. Who knew?One career mistake I made was working for organizations that never issued offer letters. At the time, I was eager to build my portfolio and gain experience, so I overlooked the importance of formal agreements. Unfortunately, it led to unclear expectations, lack of job security, and even situations where "multitasking" plus one's original job became the norm.I thought,Â â€œAs long as the work is good, everything else will fall into place.â€Â Well, it didnâ€™t.The experience taught me a vital lesson:Â Professionalism starts with structure. Today, I prioritize clarity and mutual respect in any working relationship. If a company canâ€™t provide a basic offer letter, itâ€™s a red flagâ€”not an opportunity and that is on period.To others:Â Have you had a similar experience or learned a tough lesson early in your career? Or wished you could test a feature in production â€” but only for a few users?Thatâ€™s exactly where Feature Flags shine! Turns out â€˜Weâ€™ll send it soonâ€™ isnâ€™t legally binding. Who knew?One career mistake I made was working for organizations that never issued offer letters. At the time, I was eager to build my portfolio and gain experience, so I overlooked the importance of formal agreements. Unfortunately, it led to unclear expectations, lack of job security, and even situations where "multitasking" plus one's original job became the norm.I thought,Â â€œAs long as the work is good, everything else will fall into place.â€Â Well, it didnâ€™t.The experience taught me a vital lesson:Â Professionalism starts with structure. Today, I prioritize clarity and mutual respect in any working relationship. If a company canâ€™t provide a basic offer letter, itâ€™s a red flagâ€”not an opportunity and that is on period.To others:Â Have you had a similar experience or learned a tough lesson early in your career? Iâ€™d love to hear your story.hashtag#DigitalMarketing hashtag#SocialMediaManager hashtag#EntrepreneurJourney hashtag#BrandGrowth hashtag#KendygitalMedia hashtag#StorytellingForBrands hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#ProfessionalDevelopmenthashtag#BlessingIyareLinkedInChallenge hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#ProfessionalDevelopment hashtag#30DayChallengeDay 4 of hashtag#BlessingIyareLinkedInChallenge

The Interview That Turned Into a Gym Session â€” and Then a Robbery Chronicles of a Dev Who Just Wanted a 120K Job in WestlandsIn 2019, I applied for a developer interview through LinkedIn. The job ad said:â€œTech startup hiring now! Salary 120K+. Interview in Westlands. Come prepared.â€ So far, so good. But then I saw this: â€œDress official... but carry gym wear and sport shoes.â€Weird, but okay. Maybe they value wellness culture or have a quirky onboarding process. Itâ€™s 2019, right? By 8:30 AM, We Were All SeatedWe came dressed in suits, laptops ready, resumes sharpened. Then someone walked in and said:â€œAt our company, we respect work-life balance. All new hires must experience our paid gym sessions.â€ So we were told to change into gym clothes and head to Room C49 on the 6th floor. We left our laptops, phones, shoes, and official clothes in the changing room, thinking weâ€™d be back in 45 mins. But the â€œ45-Minute Wellness Sessionâ€â€¦ Turned Into a 2-Hour TrapAerobics. Motivation speeches. Some random zumba. It felt more like orientation for a pyramid scheme than a job interview. When we came back downstairsâ€¦The changing room was locked.We asked security. They said:â€œC49? That room has had no tenant for 6 months.â€Laptops â€” gone. Phones â€” gone. Our hopes â€” vanished like an NFT market cap.We ran to Parklands Police Station, only to be told:â€œOh yeah, we know the place. Youâ€™re not the first group.â€ Final Scene Me. In boxers. No fare. No phone. No laptop. Trekking to town like a confused athlete who missed the Olympics. If an interview asks for gym clothes, it's not a job â€” it's a workout scam and always â€” always â€” carry backup fare. Turns out â€˜Weâ€™ll send it soonâ€™ isnâ€™t legally binding. Who knew?One career mistake I made was working for organizations that never issued offer letters. At the time, I was eager to build my portfolio and gain experience, so I overlooked the importance of formal agreements. Unfortunately, it led to unclear expectations, lack of job security, and even situations where "multitasking" plus one's original job became the norm.I thought,Â â€œAs long as the work is good, everything else will fall into place.â€Â Well, it didnâ€™t.The experience taught me a vital lesson:Â Professionalism starts with structure. Today, I prioritize clarity and mutual respect in any working relationship. If a company canâ€™t provide a basic offer letter, itâ€™s a red flagâ€”not an opportunity and that is on period.To others:Â Have you had a similar experience or learned a tough lesson early in your career? The Interview That Turned Into a Gym Session â€” and Then a Robbery Chronicles of a Dev Who Just Wanted a 120K Job in WestlandsIn 2019, I applied for a developer interview through LinkedIn. The job ad said:â€œTech startup hiring now! Salary 120K+. Interview in Westlands. Come prepared.â€ So far, so good. But then I saw this: â€œDress official... but carry gym wear and sport shoes.â€Weird, but okay. Maybe they value wellness culture or have a quirky onboarding process. Itâ€™s 2019, right? By 8:30 AM, We Were All SeatedWe came dressed in suits, laptops ready, resumes sharpened. Then someone walked in and said:â€œAt our company, we respect work-life balance. All new hires must experience our paid gym sessions.â€ So we were told to change into gym clothes and head to Room C49 on the 6th floor. We left our laptops, phones, shoes, and official clothes in the changing room, thinking weâ€™d be back in 45 mins. But the â€œ45-Minute Wellness Sessionâ€â€¦ Turned Into a 2-Hour TrapAerobics. Motivation speeches. Some random zumba. It felt more like orientation for a pyramid scheme than a job interview. When we came back downstairsâ€¦The changing room was locked.We asked security. They said:â€œC49? That room has had no tenant for 6 months.â€Laptops â€” gone. Phones â€” gone. Our hopes â€” vanished like an NFT market cap.We ran to Parklands Police Station, only to be told:â€œOh yeah, we know the place. Youâ€™re not the first group.â€ Final Scene Me. In boxers. No fare. No phone. No laptop. Trekking to town like a confused athlete who missed the Olympics. If an interview asks for gym clothes, it's not a job â€” it's a workout scam and always â€” always â€” carry backup fare. Nairobi is unpredictable.hashtag#JobSearchChronicles hashtag#NairobiHustle hashtag#DeveloperLife hashtag#LinkedInRealTalk hashtag#ScamAlert hashtag#WorkLifeBalanceGoneWrong hashtag#StayWoke hashtag#trending hashtag#Jobs hashtag#africa

Or wished you could test a feature in production â€” but only for a few users?Thatâ€™s exactly where Feature Flags shine! They let you turn parts of your code ON or OFF at runtime, without deploying new code. Yes, really.ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’» In .NET, using "Microsoft.FeatureManagement" makes this super easy.Hereâ€™s a quick example:if (await featureManager.IsEnabledAsync(FeatureFlags.ClipArticleContent)){ article.Content = article.Content.Substring(0, 50);}âœ… Flag ON? Turns out â€˜Weâ€™ll send it soonâ€™ isnâ€™t legally binding. Who knew?One career mistake I made was working for organizations that never issued offer letters. At the time, I was eager to build my portfolio and gain experience, so I overlooked the importance of formal agreements. Unfortunately, it led to unclear expectations, lack of job security, and even situations where "multitasking" plus one's original job became the norm.I thought,Â â€œAs long as the work is good, everything else will fall into place.â€Â Well, it didnâ€™t.The experience taught me a vital lesson:Â Professionalism starts with structure. Today, I prioritize clarity and mutual respect in any working relationship. If a company canâ€™t provide a basic offer letter, itâ€™s a red flagâ€”not an opportunity and that is on period.To others:Â Have you had a similar experience or learned a tough lesson early in your career? The Interview That Turned Into a Gym Session â€” and Then a Robbery Chronicles of a Dev Who Just Wanted a 120K Job in WestlandsIn 2019, I applied for a developer interview through LinkedIn. The job ad said:â€œTech startup hiring now! Salary 120K+. Interview in Westlands. Come prepared.â€ So far, so good. But then I saw this: â€œDress official... but carry gym wear and sport shoes.â€Weird, but okay. Maybe they value wellness culture or have a quirky onboarding process. Itâ€™s 2019, right? By 8:30 AM, We Were All SeatedWe came dressed in suits, laptops ready, resumes sharpened. Then someone walked in and said:â€œAt our company, we respect work-life balance. All new hires must experience our paid gym sessions.â€ So we were told to change into gym clothes and head to Room C49 on the 6th floor. We left our laptops, phones, shoes, and official clothes in the changing room, thinking weâ€™d be back in 45 mins. But the â€œ45-Minute Wellness Sessionâ€â€¦ Turned Into a 2-Hour TrapAerobics. Motivation speeches. Some random zumba. It felt more like orientation for a pyramid scheme than a job interview. When we came back downstairsâ€¦The changing room was locked.We asked security. They said:â€œC49? That room has had no tenant for 6 months.â€Laptops â€” gone. Phones â€” gone. Our hopes â€” vanished like an NFT market cap.We ran to Parklands Police Station, only to be told:â€œOh yeah, we know the place. Youâ€™re not the first group.â€ Final Scene Me. In boxers. No fare. No phone. No laptop. Trekking to town like a confused athlete who missed the Olympics. If an interview asks for gym clothes, it's not a job â€” it's a workout scam and always â€” always â€” carry backup fare. Nairobi is unpredictable.hashtag#JobSearchChronicles hashtag#NairobiHustle hashtag#DeveloperLife hashtag#LinkedInRealTalk hashtag#ScamAlert hashtag#WorkLifeBalanceGoneWrong hashtag#StayWoke hashtag#trending hashtag#Jobs hashtag#africa

Or wished you could test a feature in production â€” but only for a few users?Thatâ€™s exactly where Feature Flags shine! They let you turn parts of your code ON or OFF at runtime, without deploying new code. Yes, really.ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’» In .NET, using "Microsoft.FeatureManagement" makes this super easy.Hereâ€™s a quick example:if (await featureManager.IsEnabledAsync(FeatureFlags.ClipArticleContent)){ article.Content = article.Content.Substring(0, 50);}âœ… Flag ON? Turns out â€˜Weâ€™ll send it soonâ€™ isnâ€™t legally binding. Who knew?One career mistake I made was working for organizations that never issued offer letters. At the time, I was eager to build my portfolio and gain experience, so I overlooked the importance of formal agreements. Unfortunately, it led to unclear expectations, lack of job security, and even situations where "multitasking" plus one's original job became the norm.I thought,Â â€œAs long as the work is good, everything else will fall into place.â€Â Well, it didnâ€™t.The experience taught me a vital lesson:Â Professionalism starts with structure. Today, I prioritize clarity and mutual respect in any working relationship. If a company canâ€™t provide a basic offer letter, itâ€™s a red flagâ€”not an opportunity and that is on period.To others:Â Have you had a similar experience or learned a tough lesson early in your career? The Interview That Turned Into a Gym Session â€” and Then a Robbery Chronicles of a Dev Who Just Wanted a 120K Job in WestlandsIn 2019, I applied for a developer interview through LinkedIn. The job ad said:â€œTech startup hiring now! Salary 120K+. Interview in Westlands. Come prepared.â€ So far, so good. But then I saw this: â€œDress official... but carry gym wear and sport shoes.â€Weird, but okay. Maybe they value wellness culture or have a quirky onboarding process. Itâ€™s 2019, right? By 8:30 AM, We Were All SeatedWe came dressed in suits, laptops ready, resumes sharpened. Then someone walked in and said:â€œAt our company, we respect work-life balance. All new hires must experience our paid gym sessions.â€ So we were told to change into gym clothes and head to Room C49 on the 6th floor. We left our laptops, phones, shoes, and official clothes in the changing room, thinking weâ€™d be back in 45 mins. But the â€œ45-Minute Wellness Sessionâ€â€¦ Turned Into a 2-Hour TrapAerobics. Motivation speeches. Some random zumba. It felt more like orientation for a pyramid scheme than a job interview. When we came back downstairsâ€¦The changing room was locked.We asked security. They said:â€œC49? That room has had no tenant for 6 months.â€Laptops â€” gone. Phones â€” gone. Our hopes â€” vanished like an NFT market cap.We ran to Parklands Police Station, only to be told:â€œOh yeah, we know the place. Youâ€™re not the first group.â€ Final Scene Me. In boxers. No fare. No phone. No laptop. Trekking to town like a confused athlete who missed the Olympics. If an interview asks for gym clothes, it's not a job â€” it's a workout scam and always â€” always â€” carry backup fare. Nairobi is unpredictable.hashtag#JobSearchChronicles hashtag#NairobiHustle hashtag#DeveloperLife hashtag#LinkedInRealTalk hashtag#ScamAlert hashtag#WorkLifeBalanceGoneWrong hashtag#StayWoke hashtag#trending hashtag#Jobs hashtag#africa

Or wished you could test a feature in production â€” but only for a few users?Thatâ€™s exactly where Feature Flags shine! They let you turn parts of your code ON or OFF at runtime, without deploying new code. Yes, really.ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’» In .NET, using "Microsoft.FeatureManagement" makes this super easy.Hereâ€™s a quick example:if (await featureManager.IsEnabledAsync(FeatureFlags.ClipArticleContent)){ article.Content = article.Content.Substring(0, 50);}âœ… Flag ON? At the time, I was eager to build my portfolio and gain experience, so I overlooked the importance of formal agreements. Today, I prioritize clarity and mutual respect in any working relationship. The Interview That Turned Into a Gym Session â€” and Then a Robbery Chronicles of a Dev Who Just Wanted a 120K Job in WestlandsIn 2019, I applied for a developer interview through LinkedIn. The job ad said:â€œTech startup hiring now! Salary 120K+. Interview in Westlands. Come prepared.â€ So far, so good. But then I saw this: â€œDress official... but carry gym wear and sport shoes.â€Weird, but okay. Maybe they value wellness culture or have a quirky onboarding process. Itâ€™s 2019, right? By 8:30 AM, We Were All SeatedWe came dressed in suits, laptops ready, resumes sharpened. Then someone walked in and said:â€œAt our company, we respect work-life balance. All new hires must experience our paid gym sessions.â€ So we were told to change into gym clothes and head to Room C49 on the 6th floor. We left our laptops, phones, shoes, and official clothes in the changing room, thinking weâ€™d be back in 45 mins. But the â€œ45-Minute Wellness Sessionâ€â€¦ Turned Into a 2-Hour TrapAerobics. Motivation speeches. Some random zumba. It felt more like orientation for a pyramid scheme than a job interview. When we came back downstairsâ€¦The changing room was locked.We asked security. They said:â€œC49? That room has had no tenant for 6 months.â€Laptops â€” gone. Phones â€” gone. Our hopes â€” vanished like an NFT market cap.We ran to Parklands Police Station, only to be told:â€œOh yeah, we know the place. Youâ€™re not the first group.â€ Final Scene Me. In boxers. No fare. No phone. No laptop. Trekking to town like a confused athlete who missed the Olympics. If an interview asks for gym clothes, it's not a job â€” it's a workout scam and always â€” always â€” carry backup fare. Nairobi is unpredictable.hashtag#JobSearchChronicles hashtag#NairobiHustle hashtag#DeveloperLife hashtag#LinkedInRealTalk hashtag#ScamAlert hashtag#WorkLifeBalanceGoneWrong hashtag#StayWoke hashtag#trending hashtag#Jobs hashtag#africa

At the time, I was eager to build my portfolio and gain experience, so I overlooked the importance of formal agreements. Today, I prioritize clarity and mutual respect in any working relationship. The Interview That Turned Into a Gym Session â€” and Then a Robbery Chronicles of a Dev Who Just Wanted a 120K Job in WestlandsIn 2019, I applied for a developer interview through LinkedIn. The job ad said:â€œTech startup hiring now! Salary 120K+. Interview in Westlands. Come prepared.â€ So far, so good. But then I saw this: â€œDress official... but carry gym wear and sport shoes.â€Weird, but okay. Maybe they value wellness culture or have a quirky onboarding process. Itâ€™s 2019, right? By 8:30 AM, We Were All SeatedWe came dressed in suits, laptops ready, resumes sharpened. Then someone walked in and said:â€œAt our company, we respect work-life balance. All new hires must experience our paid gym sessions.â€ So we were told to change into gym clothes and head to Room C49 on the 6th floor. We left our laptops, phones, shoes, and official clothes in the changing room, thinking weâ€™d be back in 45 mins. But the â€œ45-Minute Wellness Sessionâ€â€¦ Turned Into a 2-Hour TrapAerobics. Motivation speeches. Some random zumba. It felt more like orientation for a pyramid scheme than a job interview. When we came back downstairsâ€¦The changing room was locked.We asked security. They said:â€œC49? That room has had no tenant for 6 months.â€Laptops â€” gone. Phones â€” gone. Our hopes â€” vanished like an NFT market cap.We ran to Parklands Police Station, only to be told:â€œOh yeah, we know the place. Youâ€™re not the first group.â€ Final Scene Me. In boxers. No fare. No phone. No laptop. Trekking to town like a confused athlete who missed the Olympics. If an interview asks for gym clothes, it's not a job â€” it's a workout scam and always â€” always â€” carry backup fare. Nairobi is unpredictable.hashtag#JobSearchChronicles hashtag#NairobiHustle hashtag#DeveloperLife hashtag#LinkedInRealTalk hashtag#ScamAlert hashtag#WorkLifeBalanceGoneWrong hashtag#StayWoke hashtag#trending hashtag#Jobs hashtag#africa

âœ… "Feature Flags in .NET â€“ Control Your Releases Smarter"ğŸš€ Ever released a new featureâ€¦ only to immediately roll it back due to unexpected issues? Or wished you could test a feature in production â€” but only for a few users?Thatâ€™s exactly where Feature Flags shine! They let you turn parts of your code ON or OFF at runtime, without deploying new code. Yes, really.ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’» In .NET, using "Microsoft.FeatureManagement" makes this super easy.Hereâ€™s a quick example:if (await featureManager.IsEnabledAsync(FeatureFlags.ClipArticleContent)){ article.Content = article.Content.Substring(0, 50);}âœ… Flag ON? Clip content.âŒ Flag OFF? Return full content.ğŸ” All runtime controlled â€” no redeploys!ğŸ’¡ Use cases:*Gradual rollouts (10% of users â†’ 100%)*Kill switches for unstable features*A/B testing*Ops-controlled togglesBut hereâ€™s the catch ğŸ‘‰ Adding flags is easy. Cleaning them up later is crucial. Otherwise, your codebase becomes a flag graveyard. â˜ ï¸ğŸ¨ Image Idea to explain this example of code  visaully : User â†’ API â†’ FeatureManager  | [Flag ON] â€” Shorten content [Flag OFF] â€” Return full contentâš™ï¸ How It Works:1-Check the Feature Flag: The application checks if a specific feature flag is enabled using the FeatureManager.2-Flag Disabled ("No"): If the flag is off, the app executes the fallback logic (e.g., reverting to a previous version of functionality).3-Flag Enabled ("Yes"): If the flag is on, the app proceeds with the new feature or functionality.ğŸ’¬Have you used feature flags in your apps? Turns out â€˜Weâ€™ll send it soonâ€™ isnâ€™t legally binding. Who knew?One career mistake I made was working for organizations that never issued offer letters. At the time, I was eager to build my portfolio and gain experience, so I overlooked the importance of formal agreements. Unfortunately, it led to unclear expectations, lack of job security, and even situations where "multitasking" plus one's original job became the norm.I thought,Â â€œAs long as the work is good, everything else will fall into place.â€Â Well, it didnâ€™t.The experience taught me a vital lesson:Â Professionalism starts with structure. Today, I prioritize clarity and mutual respect in any working relationship. If a company canâ€™t provide a basic offer letter, itâ€™s a red flagâ€”not an opportunity and that is on period.To others:Â Have you had a similar experience or learned a tough lesson early in your career? The Interview That Turned Into a Gym Session â€” and Then a Robbery Chronicles of a Dev Who Just Wanted a 120K Job in WestlandsIn 2019, I applied for a developer interview through LinkedIn. The job ad said:â€œTech startup hiring now! Salary 120K+. Interview in Westlands. Come prepared.â€ So far, so good. But then I saw this: â€œDress official... but carry gym wear and sport shoes.â€Weird, but okay. Maybe they value wellness culture or have a quirky onboarding process. Itâ€™s 2019, right? By 8:30 AM, We Were All SeatedWe came dressed in suits, laptops ready, resumes sharpened. Then someone walked in and said:â€œAt our company, we respect work-life balance. All new hires must experience our paid gym sessions.â€ So we were told to change into gym clothes and head to Room C49 on the 6th floor. We left our laptops, phones, shoes, and official clothes in the changing room, thinking weâ€™d be back in 45 mins. But the â€œ45-Minute Wellness Sessionâ€â€¦ Turned Into a 2-Hour TrapAerobics. Motivation speeches. Some random zumba. It felt more like orientation for a pyramid scheme than a job interview. When we came back downstairsâ€¦The changing room was locked.We asked security. They said:â€œC49? That room has had no tenant for 6 months.â€Laptops â€” gone. Phones â€” gone. Our hopes â€” vanished like an NFT market cap.We ran to Parklands Police Station, only to be told:â€œOh yeah, we know the place. Youâ€™re not the first group.â€ Final Scene Me. In boxers. No fare. No phone. No laptop. Trekking to town like a confused athlete who missed the Olympics. If an interview asks for gym clothes, it's not a job â€” it's a workout scam and always â€” always â€” carry backup fare. Nairobi is unpredictable.hashtag#JobSearchChronicles hashtag#NairobiHustle hashtag#DeveloperLife hashtag#LinkedInRealTalk hashtag#ScamAlert hashtag#WorkLifeBalanceGoneWrong hashtag#StayWoke hashtag#trending hashtag#Jobs hashtag#africa

At the time, I was eager to build my portfolio and gain experience, so I overlooked the importance of formal agreements. Today, I prioritize clarity and mutual respect in any working relationship. The Interview That Turned Into a Gym Session â€” and Then a Robbery Chronicles of a Dev Who Just Wanted a 120K Job in WestlandsIn 2019, I applied for a developer interview through LinkedIn. The job ad said:â€œTech startup hiring now! Salary 120K+. Interview in Westlands. Come prepared.â€ So far, so good. But then I saw this: â€œDress official... but carry gym wear and sport shoes.â€Weird, but okay. Maybe they value wellness culture or have a quirky onboarding process. Itâ€™s 2019, right? By 8:30 AM, We Were All SeatedWe came dressed in suits, laptops ready, resumes sharpened. Then someone walked in and said:â€œAt our company, we respect work-life balance. All new hires must experience our paid gym sessions.â€ So we were told to change into gym clothes and head to Room C49 on the 6th floor. We left our laptops, phones, shoes, and official clothes in the changing room, thinking weâ€™d be back in 45 mins. But the â€œ45-Minute Wellness Sessionâ€â€¦ Turned Into a 2-Hour TrapAerobics. Motivation speeches. Some random zumba. It felt more like orientation for a pyramid scheme than a job interview. When we came back downstairsâ€¦The changing room was locked.We asked security. They said:â€œC49? That room has had no tenant for 6 months.â€Laptops â€” gone. Phones â€” gone. Our hopes â€” vanished like an NFT market cap.We ran to Parklands Police Station, only to be told:â€œOh yeah, we know the place. Youâ€™re not the first group.â€ Final Scene Me. In boxers. No fare. No phone. No laptop. Trekking to town like a confused athlete who missed the Olympics. If an interview asks for gym clothes, it's not a job â€” it's a workout scam and always â€” always â€” carry backup fare. Nairobi is unpredictable.hashtag#JobSearchChronicles hashtag#NairobiHustle hashtag#DeveloperLife hashtag#LinkedInRealTalk hashtag#ScamAlert hashtag#WorkLifeBalanceGoneWrong hashtag#StayWoke hashtag#trending hashtag#Jobs hashtag#africa

At the time, I was eager to build my portfolio and gain experience, so I overlooked the importance of formal agreements. Today, I prioritize clarity and mutual respect in any working relationship. The Interview That Turned Into a Gym Session â€” and Then a Robbery Chronicles of a Dev Who Just Wanted a 120K Job in WestlandsIn 2019, I applied for a developer interview through LinkedIn. The job ad said:â€œTech startup hiring now! Salary 120K+. Interview in Westlands. Come prepared.â€ So far, so good. But then I saw this: â€œDress official... but carry gym wear and sport shoes.â€Weird, but okay. Maybe they value wellness culture or have a quirky onboarding process. Itâ€™s 2019, right? By 8:30 AM, We Were All SeatedWe came dressed in suits, laptops ready, resumes sharpened. Then someone walked in and said:â€œAt our company, we respect work-life balance. All new hires must experience our paid gym sessions.â€ So we were told to change into gym clothes and head to Room C49 on the 6th floor. We left our laptops, phones, shoes, and official clothes in the changing room, thinking weâ€™d be back in 45 mins. But the â€œ45-Minute Wellness Sessionâ€â€¦ Turned Into a 2-Hour TrapAerobics. Motivation speeches. Some random zumba. It felt more like orientation for a pyramid scheme than a job interview. When we came back downstairsâ€¦The changing room was locked.We asked security. They said:â€œC49? That room has had no tenant for 6 months.â€Laptops â€” gone. Phones â€” gone. Our hopes â€” vanished like an NFT market cap.We ran to Parklands Police Station, only to be told:â€œOh yeah, we know the place. Youâ€™re not the first group.â€ Final Scene Me. In boxers. No fare. No phone. No laptop. Trekking to town like a confused athlete who missed the Olympics. If an interview asks for gym clothes, it's not a job â€” it's a workout scam and always â€” always â€” carry backup fare. Nairobi is unpredictable.hashtag#JobSearchChronicles hashtag#NairobiHustle hashtag#DeveloperLife hashtag#LinkedInRealTalk hashtag#ScamAlert hashtag#WorkLifeBalanceGoneWrong hashtag#StayWoke hashtag#trending hashtag#Jobs hashtag#africa

Or wished you could test a feature in production â€” but only for a few users?Thatâ€™s exactly where Feature Flags shine! They let you turn parts of your code ON or OFF at runtime, without deploying new code. Yes, really.ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’» In .NET, using "Microsoft.FeatureManagement" makes this super easy.Hereâ€™s a quick example:if (await featureManager.IsEnabledAsync(FeatureFlags.ClipArticleContent)){ article.Content = article.Content.Substring(0, 50);}âœ… Flag ON? At the time, I was eager to build my portfolio and gain experience, so I overlooked the importance of formal agreements. Today, I prioritize clarity and mutual respect in any working relationship. The Interview That Turned Into a Gym Session â€” and Then a Robbery Chronicles of a Dev Who Just Wanted a 120K Job in WestlandsIn 2019, I applied for a developer interview through LinkedIn. The job ad said:â€œTech startup hiring now! Salary 120K+. Interview in Westlands. Come prepared.â€ So far, so good. But then I saw this: â€œDress official... but carry gym wear and sport shoes.â€Weird, but okay. Maybe they value wellness culture or have a quirky onboarding process. Itâ€™s 2019, right? By 8:30 AM, We Were All SeatedWe came dressed in suits, laptops ready, resumes sharpened. Then someone walked in and said:â€œAt our company, we respect work-life balance. All new hires must experience our paid gym sessions.â€ So we were told to change into gym clothes and head to Room C49 on the 6th floor. We left our laptops, phones, shoes, and official clothes in the changing room, thinking weâ€™d be back in 45 mins. But the â€œ45-Minute Wellness Sessionâ€â€¦ Turned Into a 2-Hour TrapAerobics. Motivation speeches. Some random zumba. It felt more like orientation for a pyramid scheme than a job interview. When we came back downstairsâ€¦The changing room was locked.We asked security. They said:â€œC49? That room has had no tenant for 6 months.â€Laptops â€” gone. Phones â€” gone. Our hopes â€” vanished like an NFT market cap.We ran to Parklands Police Station, only to be told:â€œOh yeah, we know the place. Youâ€™re not the first group.â€ Final Scene Me. In boxers. No fare. No phone. No laptop. Trekking to town like a confused athlete who missed the Olympics. If an interview asks for gym clothes, it's not a job â€” it's a workout scam and always â€” always â€” carry backup fare. Nairobi is unpredictable.hashtag#JobSearchChronicles hashtag#NairobiHustle hashtag#DeveloperLife hashtag#LinkedInRealTalk hashtag#ScamAlert hashtag#WorkLifeBalanceGoneWrong hashtag#StayWoke hashtag#trending hashtag#Jobs hashtag#africa

ğŸš€ Introducing EventX â€“ A Universal Event Manager for .NET Apps ğŸ§ âš™ï¸In modern apps, components often need to react to things happening elsewhere â€” a product added to cart, a user logging in, a notification being dismissed. But wiring this up cleanly across unrelated components can be messy, especially in larger Blazor or MAUI apps.Thatâ€™s where EventX comes in â€” a lightweight, thread-safe C# library that brings event-driven architecture to your .NET apps, with zero boilerplate.ğŸ”§ What it does:ğŸ” Publish/subscribe to events across the app (sync & async)ğŸ”’ Strongly-typed and memory-leak safeğŸš« Auto-remove listeners with .Once()âœ… Works in Blazor (Server/WASM), MAUI, WPF, etc.ğŸ“¦ Real-World Use Cases:ğŸ›’ Mini Cart updates in E-commerce appsğŸ”” Toast Notifications triggered globallyğŸ“£ Multi-tab communication (via BroadcastChannel)ğŸ§  Loose coupling between services and UIğŸ•µï¸â€â™‚ï¸ Debugging memory leaks with scoped unsubscriptionHere's the beauty: with EventX, your components donâ€™t need to know who is listening â€” they just fire an event, and magic happens ğŸ’¥Visit the link to know more:https://lnkd.in/dvjefT8Ghashtag#dotnet hashtag#csharp hashtag#blazor hashtag#blazorwasm hashtag#dotnetcore hashtag#eventdrivenarchitecture hashtag#developerexperience hashtag#webdevelopment hashtag#frontenddevelopment hashtag#backenddevelopment hashtag#aspnetcore hashtag#softwarearchitecture hashtag#opensource hashtag#dependencyinjection hashtag#eventdriven hashtag#devtools hashtag#programming hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#reactivity hashtag#multitab hashtag#browserapi hashtag#broadcastchannel hashtag#scalability hashtag#modulararchitecture hashtag#cleanarchitecture

ğŸ”¹ ASP.NET Core Middleware Pipeline â€“ Part 4: Static Files MiddlewareOnce HTTPS is enforced, the next step in the pipeline is enabling your app to serve static content like images, CSS, JavaScript, and other assets.ğŸ—‚ï¸ What does Static Files Middleware do? It allows your ASP.NET Core app to serve files directly from the wwwroot folder (or any configured directory) without needing any controller logic.ğŸ“¦ UseStaticFiles() This middleware scans for static files and returns them if found, bypassing the rest of the pipeline.app.UseStaticFiles();ğŸ“ For example, if you have:wwwroot/css/site.cssA browser can request it at:https://lnkd.in/dnn8CzJbâš ï¸ Security Tip: By default, only the wwwroot folder is accessible. Avoid serving sensitive files by accidentally exposing other directories.ğŸ§  Best Practice: Place UseStaticFiles() early in the pipeline so static content is returned before more complex processing (like routing or authentication).ğŸš€ Coming up next: Routing Middleware â€” the backbone of request processing.hashtag#ASPNETCore hashtag#Middleware hashtag#DotNet hashtag#StaticFiles hashtag#WebDev hashtag#CSharp hashtag#BackendDevelopment

At the time, I was eager to build my portfolio and gain experience, so I overlooked the importance of formal agreements. Today, I prioritize clarity and mutual respect in any working relationship. The Interview That Turned Into a Gym Session â€” and Then a Robbery Chronicles of a Dev Who Just Wanted a 120K Job in WestlandsIn 2019, I applied for a developer interview through LinkedIn. The job ad said:â€œTech startup hiring now! Salary 120K+. Interview in Westlands. Come prepared.â€ So far, so good. But then I saw this: â€œDress official... but carry gym wear and sport shoes.â€Weird, but okay. Maybe they value wellness culture or have a quirky onboarding process. Itâ€™s 2019, right? By 8:30 AM, We Were All SeatedWe came dressed in suits, laptops ready, resumes sharpened. Then someone walked in and said:â€œAt our company, we respect work-life balance. All new hires must experience our paid gym sessions.â€ So we were told to change into gym clothes and head to Room C49 on the 6th floor. We left our laptops, phones, shoes, and official clothes in the changing room, thinking weâ€™d be back in 45 mins. But the â€œ45-Minute Wellness Sessionâ€â€¦ Turned Into a 2-Hour TrapAerobics. Motivation speeches. Some random zumba. It felt more like orientation for a pyramid scheme than a job interview. When we came back downstairsâ€¦The changing room was locked.We asked security. They said:â€œC49? That room has had no tenant for 6 months.â€Laptops â€” gone. Phones â€” gone. Our hopes â€” vanished like an NFT market cap.We ran to Parklands Police Station, only to be told:â€œOh yeah, we know the place. Youâ€™re not the first group.â€ Final Scene Me. In boxers. No fare. No phone. No laptop. Trekking to town like a confused athlete who missed the Olympics. If an interview asks for gym clothes, it's not a job â€” it's a workout scam and always â€” always â€” carry backup fare. Nairobi is unpredictable.hashtag#JobSearchChronicles hashtag#NairobiHustle hashtag#DeveloperLife hashtag#LinkedInRealTalk hashtag#ScamAlert hashtag#WorkLifeBalanceGoneWrong hashtag#StayWoke hashtag#trending hashtag#Jobs hashtag#africa

ğŸš€ Introducing EventX â€“ A Universal Event Manager for .NET Apps ğŸ§ âš™ï¸In modern apps, components often need to react to things happening elsewhere â€” a product added to cart, a user logging in, a notification being dismissed. But wiring this up cleanly across unrelated components can be messy, especially in larger Blazor or MAUI apps.Thatâ€™s where EventX comes in â€” a lightweight, thread-safe C# library that brings event-driven architecture to your .NET apps, with zero boilerplate.ğŸ”§ What it does:ğŸ” Publish/subscribe to events across the app (sync & async)ğŸ”’ Strongly-typed and memory-leak safeğŸš« Auto-remove listeners with .Once()âœ… Works in Blazor (Server/WASM), MAUI, WPF, etc.ğŸ“¦ Real-World Use Cases:ğŸ›’ Mini Cart updates in E-commerce appsğŸ”” Toast Notifications triggered globallyğŸ“£ Multi-tab communication (via BroadcastChannel)ğŸ§  Loose coupling between services and UIğŸ•µï¸â€â™‚ï¸ Debugging memory leaks with scoped unsubscriptionHere's the beauty: with EventX, your components donâ€™t need to know who is listening â€” they just fire an event, and magic happens ğŸ’¥Visit the link to know more:https://lnkd.in/dvjefT8Ghashtag#dotnet hashtag#csharp hashtag#blazor hashtag#blazorwasm hashtag#dotnetcore hashtag#eventdrivenarchitecture hashtag#developerexperience hashtag#webdevelopment hashtag#frontenddevelopment hashtag#backenddevelopment hashtag#aspnetcore hashtag#softwarearchitecture hashtag#opensource hashtag#dependencyinjection hashtag#eventdriven hashtag#devtools hashtag#programming hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#reactivity hashtag#multitab hashtag#browserapi hashtag#broadcastchannel hashtag#scalability hashtag#modulararchitecture hashtag#cleanarchitecture

ğŸ”¹ ASP.NET Core Middleware Pipeline â€“ Part 4: Static Files MiddlewareOnce HTTPS is enforced, the next step in the pipeline is enabling your app to serve static content like images, CSS, JavaScript, and other assets.ğŸ—‚ï¸ What does Static Files Middleware do? It allows your ASP.NET Core app to serve files directly from the wwwroot folder (or any configured directory) without needing any controller logic.ğŸ“¦ UseStaticFiles() This middleware scans for static files and returns them if found, bypassing the rest of the pipeline.app.UseStaticFiles();ğŸ“ For example, if you have:wwwroot/css/site.cssA browser can request it at:https://lnkd.in/dnn8CzJbâš ï¸ Security Tip: By default, only the wwwroot folder is accessible. Avoid serving sensitive files by accidentally exposing other directories.ğŸ§  Best Practice: Place UseStaticFiles() early in the pipeline so static content is returned before more complex processing (like routing or authentication).ğŸš€ Coming up next: Routing Middleware â€” the backbone of request processing.hashtag#ASPNETCore hashtag#Middleware hashtag#DotNet hashtag#StaticFiles hashtag#WebDev hashtag#CSharp hashtag#BackendDevelopment

At the time, I was eager to build my portfolio and gain experience, so I overlooked the importance of formal agreements. Today, I prioritize clarity and mutual respect in any working relationship. The Interview That Turned Into a Gym Session â€” and Then a Robbery Chronicles of a Dev Who Just Wanted a 120K Job in WestlandsIn 2019, I applied for a developer interview through LinkedIn. The job ad said:â€œTech startup hiring now! Salary 120K+. Interview in Westlands. Come prepared.â€ So far, so good. But then I saw this: â€œDress official... but carry gym wear and sport shoes.â€Weird, but okay. Maybe they value wellness culture or have a quirky onboarding process. Itâ€™s 2019, right? By 8:30 AM, We Were All SeatedWe came dressed in suits, laptops ready, resumes sharpened. Then someone walked in and said:â€œAt our company, we respect work-life balance. All new hires must experience our paid gym sessions.â€ So we were told to change into gym clothes and head to Room C49 on the 6th floor. We left our laptops, phones, shoes, and official clothes in the changing room, thinking weâ€™d be back in 45 mins. But the â€œ45-Minute Wellness Sessionâ€â€¦ Turned Into a 2-Hour TrapAerobics. Motivation speeches. Some random zumba. It felt more like orientation for a pyramid scheme than a job interview. When we came back downstairsâ€¦The changing room was locked.We asked security. They said:â€œC49? That room has had no tenant for 6 months.â€Laptops â€” gone. Phones â€” gone. Our hopes â€” vanished like an NFT market cap.We ran to Parklands Police Station, only to be told:â€œOh yeah, we know the place. Youâ€™re not the first group.â€ Final Scene Me. In boxers. No fare. No phone. No laptop. Trekking to town like a confused athlete who missed the Olympics. If an interview asks for gym clothes, it's not a job â€” it's a workout scam and always â€” always â€” carry backup fare. Nairobi is unpredictable.hashtag#JobSearchChronicles hashtag#NairobiHustle hashtag#DeveloperLife hashtag#LinkedInRealTalk hashtag#ScamAlert hashtag#WorkLifeBalanceGoneWrong hashtag#StayWoke hashtag#trending hashtag#Jobs hashtag#africa

ğŸš€ Introducing EventX â€“ A Universal Event Manager for .NET Apps ğŸ§ âš™ï¸In modern apps, components often need to react to things happening elsewhere â€” a product added to cart, a user logging in, a notification being dismissed. But wiring this up cleanly across unrelated components can be messy, especially in larger Blazor or MAUI apps.Thatâ€™s where EventX comes in â€” a lightweight, thread-safe C# library that brings event-driven architecture to your .NET apps, with zero boilerplate.ğŸ”§ What it does:ğŸ” Publish/subscribe to events across the app (sync & async)ğŸ”’ Strongly-typed and memory-leak safeğŸš« Auto-remove listeners with .Once()âœ… Works in Blazor (Server/WASM), MAUI, WPF, etc.ğŸ“¦ Real-World Use Cases:ğŸ›’ Mini Cart updates in E-commerce appsğŸ”” Toast Notifications triggered globallyğŸ“£ Multi-tab communication (via BroadcastChannel)ğŸ§  Loose coupling between services and UIğŸ•µï¸â€â™‚ï¸ Debugging memory leaks with scoped unsubscriptionHere's the beauty: with EventX, your components donâ€™t need to know who is listening â€” they just fire an event, and magic happens ğŸ’¥Visit the link to know more:https://lnkd.in/dvjefT8Ghashtag#dotnet hashtag#csharp hashtag#blazor hashtag#blazorwasm hashtag#dotnetcore hashtag#eventdrivenarchitecture hashtag#developerexperience hashtag#webdevelopment hashtag#frontenddevelopment hashtag#backenddevelopment hashtag#aspnetcore hashtag#softwarearchitecture hashtag#opensource hashtag#dependencyinjection hashtag#eventdriven hashtag#devtools hashtag#programming hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#reactivity hashtag#multitab hashtag#browserapi hashtag#broadcastchannel hashtag#scalability hashtag#modulararchitecture hashtag#cleanarchitecture

ğŸ”¹ ASP.NET Core Middleware Pipeline â€“ Part 4: Static Files MiddlewareOnce HTTPS is enforced, the next step in the pipeline is enabling your app to serve static content like images, CSS, JavaScript, and other assets.ğŸ—‚ï¸ What does Static Files Middleware do? It allows your ASP.NET Core app to serve files directly from the wwwroot folder (or any configured directory) without needing any controller logic.ğŸ“¦ UseStaticFiles() This middleware scans for static files and returns them if found, bypassing the rest of the pipeline.app.UseStaticFiles();ğŸ“ For example, if you have:wwwroot/css/site.cssA browser can request it at:https://lnkd.in/dnn8CzJbâš ï¸ Security Tip: By default, only the wwwroot folder is accessible. Avoid serving sensitive files by accidentally exposing other directories.ğŸ§  Best Practice: Place UseStaticFiles() early in the pipeline so static content is returned before more complex processing (like routing or authentication).ğŸš€ Coming up next: Routing Middleware â€” the backbone of request processing.hashtag#ASPNETCore hashtag#Middleware hashtag#DotNet hashtag#StaticFiles hashtag#WebDev hashtag#CSharp hashtag#BackendDevelopment

âœ… "Feature Flags in .NET â€“ Control Your Releases Smarter"ğŸš€ Ever released a new featureâ€¦ only to immediately roll it back due to unexpected issues? Or wished you could test a feature in production â€” but only for a few users?Thatâ€™s exactly where Feature Flags shine! They let you turn parts of your code ON or OFF at runtime, without deploying new code. Yes, really.ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’» In .NET, using "Microsoft.FeatureManagement" makes this super easy.Hereâ€™s a quick example:if (await featureManager.IsEnabledAsync(FeatureFlags.ClipArticleContent)){ article.Content = article.Content.Substring(0, 50);}âœ… Flag ON? Clip content.âŒ Flag OFF? Return full content.ğŸ” All runtime controlled â€” no redeploys!ğŸ’¡ Use cases:*Gradual rollouts (10% of users â†’ 100%)*Kill switches for unstable features*A/B testing*Ops-controlled togglesBut hereâ€™s the catch ğŸ‘‰ Adding flags is easy. Cleaning them up later is crucial. Otherwise, your codebase becomes a flag graveyard. â˜ ï¸ğŸ¨ Image Idea to explain this example of code  visaully : User â†’ API â†’ FeatureManager  | [Flag ON] â€” Shorten content [Flag OFF] â€” Return full contentâš™ï¸ How It Works:1-Check the Feature Flag: The application checks if a specific feature flag is enabled using the FeatureManager.2-Flag Disabled ("No"): If the flag is off, the app executes the fallback logic (e.g., reverting to a previous version of functionality).3-Flag Enabled ("Yes"): If the flag is on, the app proceeds with the new feature or functionality.ğŸ’¬Have you used feature flags in your apps? At the time, I was eager to build my portfolio and gain experience, so I overlooked the importance of formal agreements. Today, I prioritize clarity and mutual respect in any working relationship. The Interview That Turned Into a Gym Session â€” and Then a Robbery Chronicles of a Dev Who Just Wanted a 120K Job in WestlandsIn 2019, I applied for a developer interview through LinkedIn. The job ad said:â€œTech startup hiring now! Salary 120K+. Interview in Westlands. Come prepared.â€ So far, so good. But then I saw this: â€œDress official... but carry gym wear and sport shoes.â€Weird, but okay. Maybe they value wellness culture or have a quirky onboarding process. Itâ€™s 2019, right? By 8:30 AM, We Were All SeatedWe came dressed in suits, laptops ready, resumes sharpened. Then someone walked in and said:â€œAt our company, we respect work-life balance. All new hires must experience our paid gym sessions.â€ So we were told to change into gym clothes and head to Room C49 on the 6th floor. We left our laptops, phones, shoes, and official clothes in the changing room, thinking weâ€™d be back in 45 mins. But the â€œ45-Minute Wellness Sessionâ€â€¦ Turned Into a 2-Hour TrapAerobics. Motivation speeches. Some random zumba. It felt more like orientation for a pyramid scheme than a job interview. When we came back downstairsâ€¦The changing room was locked.We asked security. They said:â€œC49? That room has had no tenant for 6 months.â€Laptops â€” gone. Phones â€” gone. Our hopes â€” vanished like an NFT market cap.We ran to Parklands Police Station, only to be told:â€œOh yeah, we know the place. Youâ€™re not the first group.â€ Final Scene Me. In boxers. No fare. No phone. No laptop. Trekking to town like a confused athlete who missed the Olympics. If an interview asks for gym clothes, it's not a job â€” it's a workout scam and always â€” always â€” carry backup fare. Nairobi is unpredictable.hashtag#JobSearchChronicles hashtag#NairobiHustle hashtag#DeveloperLife hashtag#LinkedInRealTalk hashtag#ScamAlert hashtag#WorkLifeBalanceGoneWrong hashtag#StayWoke hashtag#trending hashtag#Jobs hashtag#africa

ğŸ”¹ ASP.NET Core Middleware Pipeline â€“ Part 4: Static Files MiddlewareOnce HTTPS is enforced, the next step in the pipeline is enabling your app to serve static content like images, CSS, JavaScript, and other assets.ğŸ—‚ï¸ What does Static Files Middleware do? It allows your ASP.NET Core app to serve files directly from the wwwroot folder (or any configured directory) without needing any controller logic.ğŸ“¦ UseStaticFiles() This middleware scans for static files and returns them if found, bypassing the rest of the pipeline.app.UseStaticFiles();ğŸ“ For example, if you have:wwwroot/css/site.cssA browser can request it at:https://lnkd.in/dnn8CzJbâš ï¸ Security Tip: By default, only the wwwroot folder is accessible. Avoid serving sensitive files by accidentally exposing other directories.ğŸ§  Best Practice: Place UseStaticFiles() early in the pipeline so static content is returned before more complex processing (like routing or authentication).ğŸš€ Coming up next: Routing Middleware â€” the backbone of request processing.hashtag#ASPNETCore hashtag#Middleware hashtag#DotNet hashtag#StaticFiles hashtag#WebDev hashtag#CSharp hashtag#BackendDevelopment

While AutoMapper is popular for reducing boilerplate and speeding up development with its convention-based approach, it can sometimes make the mapping process less transparent as projects grow and debugging becomes more complex. Although it might mean writing a bit more code upfront, using well-crafted static mapping methods offers improved performance through inlining and compile-time checks. âœ… "Feature Flags in .NET â€“ Control Your Releases Smarter"ğŸš€ Ever released a new featureâ€¦ only to immediately roll it back due to unexpected issues? Or wished you could test a feature in production â€” but only for a few users?Thatâ€™s exactly where Feature Flags shine! They let you turn parts of your code ON or OFF at runtime, without deploying new code. Yes, really.ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’» In .NET, using "Microsoft.FeatureManagement" makes this super easy.Hereâ€™s a quick example:if (await featureManager.IsEnabledAsync(FeatureFlags.ClipArticleContent)){ article.Content = article.Content.Substring(0, 50);}âœ… Flag ON? Clip content.âŒ Flag OFF? Return full content.ğŸ” All runtime controlled â€” no redeploys!ğŸ’¡ Use cases:*Gradual rollouts (10% of users â†’ 100%)*Kill switches for unstable features*A/B testing*Ops-controlled togglesBut hereâ€™s the catch ğŸ‘‰ Adding flags is easy. Cleaning them up later is crucial. Otherwise, your codebase becomes a flag graveyard. â˜ ï¸ğŸ¨ Image Idea to explain this example of code  visaully : User â†’ API â†’ FeatureManager  | [Flag ON] â€” Shorten content [Flag OFF] â€” Return full contentâš™ï¸ How It Works:1-Check the Feature Flag: The application checks if a specific feature flag is enabled using the FeatureManager.2-Flag Disabled ("No"): If the flag is off, the app executes the fallback logic (e.g., reverting to a previous version of functionality).3-Flag Enabled ("Yes"): If the flag is on, the app proceeds with the new feature or functionality.ğŸ’¬Have you used feature flags in your apps? Turns out â€˜Weâ€™ll send it soonâ€™ isnâ€™t legally binding. Who knew?One career mistake I made was working for organizations that never issued offer letters. At the time, I was eager to build my portfolio and gain experience, so I overlooked the importance of formal agreements. Unfortunately, it led to unclear expectations, lack of job security, and even situations where "multitasking" plus one's original job became the norm.I thought,Â â€œAs long as the work is good, everything else will fall into place.â€Â Well, it didnâ€™t.The experience taught me a vital lesson:Â Professionalism starts with structure. Today, I prioritize clarity and mutual respect in any working relationship. If a company canâ€™t provide a basic offer letter, itâ€™s a red flagâ€”not an opportunity and that is on period.To others:Â Have you had a similar experience or learned a tough lesson early in your career? The Interview That Turned Into a Gym Session â€” and Then a Robbery Chronicles of a Dev Who Just Wanted a 120K Job in WestlandsIn 2019, I applied for a developer interview through LinkedIn. The job ad said:â€œTech startup hiring now! Salary 120K+. Interview in Westlands. Come prepared.â€ So far, so good. But then I saw this: â€œDress official... but carry gym wear and sport shoes.â€Weird, but okay. Maybe they value wellness culture or have a quirky onboarding process. Itâ€™s 2019, right? By 8:30 AM, We Were All SeatedWe came dressed in suits, laptops ready, resumes sharpened. Then someone walked in and said:â€œAt our company, we respect work-life balance. All new hires must experience our paid gym sessions.â€ So we were told to change into gym clothes and head to Room C49 on the 6th floor. We left our laptops, phones, shoes, and official clothes in the changing room, thinking weâ€™d be back in 45 mins. But the â€œ45-Minute Wellness Sessionâ€â€¦ Turned Into a 2-Hour TrapAerobics. Motivation speeches. Some random zumba. It felt more like orientation for a pyramid scheme than a job interview. When we came back downstairsâ€¦The changing room was locked.We asked security. They said:â€œC49? That room has had no tenant for 6 months.â€Laptops â€” gone. Phones â€” gone. Our hopes â€” vanished like an NFT market cap.We ran to Parklands Police Station, only to be told:â€œOh yeah, we know the place. Youâ€™re not the first group.â€ Final Scene Me. In boxers. No fare. No phone. No laptop. Trekking to town like a confused athlete who missed the Olympics. If an interview asks for gym clothes, it's not a job â€” it's a workout scam and always â€” always â€” carry backup fare. Nairobi is unpredictable.hashtag#JobSearchChronicles hashtag#NairobiHustle hashtag#DeveloperLife hashtag#LinkedInRealTalk hashtag#ScamAlert hashtag#WorkLifeBalanceGoneWrong hashtag#StayWoke hashtag#trending hashtag#Jobs hashtag#africa

ğŸ”¹ ASP.NET Core Middleware Pipeline â€“ Part 4: Static Files MiddlewareOnce HTTPS is enforced, the next step in the pipeline is enabling your app to serve static content like images, CSS, JavaScript, and other assets.ğŸ—‚ï¸ What does Static Files Middleware do? It allows your ASP.NET Core app to serve files directly from the wwwroot folder (or any configured directory) without needing any controller logic.ğŸ“¦ UseStaticFiles() This middleware scans for static files and returns them if found, bypassing the rest of the pipeline.app.UseStaticFiles();ğŸ“ For example, if you have:wwwroot/css/site.cssA browser can request it at:https://lnkd.in/dnn8CzJbâš ï¸ Security Tip: By default, only the wwwroot folder is accessible. Avoid serving sensitive files by accidentally exposing other directories.ğŸ§  Best Practice: Place UseStaticFiles() early in the pipeline so static content is returned before more complex processing (like routing or authentication).ğŸš€ Coming up next: Routing Middleware â€” the backbone of request processing.hashtag#ASPNETCore hashtag#Middleware hashtag#DotNet hashtag#StaticFiles hashtag#WebDev hashtag#CSharp hashtag#BackendDevelopment

At the time, I was eager to build my portfolio and gain experience, so I overlooked the importance of formal agreements. Today, I prioritize clarity and mutual respect in any working relationship. The Interview That Turned Into a Gym Session â€” and Then a Robbery Chronicles of a Dev Who Just Wanted a 120K Job in WestlandsIn 2019, I applied for a developer interview through LinkedIn. The job ad said:â€œTech startup hiring now! Salary 120K+. Interview in Westlands. Come prepared.â€ So far, so good. But then I saw this: â€œDress official... but carry gym wear and sport shoes.â€Weird, but okay. Maybe they value wellness culture or have a quirky onboarding process. Itâ€™s 2019, right? By 8:30 AM, We Were All SeatedWe came dressed in suits, laptops ready, resumes sharpened. Then someone walked in and said:â€œAt our company, we respect work-life balance. All new hires must experience our paid gym sessions.â€ So we were told to change into gym clothes and head to Room C49 on the 6th floor. We left our laptops, phones, shoes, and official clothes in the changing room, thinking weâ€™d be back in 45 mins. But the â€œ45-Minute Wellness Sessionâ€â€¦ Turned Into a 2-Hour TrapAerobics. Motivation speeches. Some random zumba. It felt more like orientation for a pyramid scheme than a job interview. When we came back downstairsâ€¦The changing room was locked.We asked security. They said:â€œC49? That room has had no tenant for 6 months.â€Laptops â€” gone. Phones â€” gone. Our hopes â€” vanished like an NFT market cap.We ran to Parklands Police Station, only to be told:â€œOh yeah, we know the place. Youâ€™re not the first group.â€ Final Scene Me. In boxers. No fare. No phone. No laptop. Trekking to town like a confused athlete who missed the Olympics. If an interview asks for gym clothes, it's not a job â€” it's a workout scam and always â€” always â€” carry backup fare. Nairobi is unpredictable.hashtag#JobSearchChronicles hashtag#NairobiHustle hashtag#DeveloperLife hashtag#LinkedInRealTalk hashtag#ScamAlert hashtag#WorkLifeBalanceGoneWrong hashtag#StayWoke hashtag#trending hashtag#Jobs hashtag#africa

ğŸš€ Introducing EventX â€“ A Universal Event Manager for .NET Apps ğŸ§ âš™ï¸In modern apps, components often need to react to things happening elsewhere â€” a product added to cart, a user logging in, a notification being dismissed. But wiring this up cleanly across unrelated components can be messy, especially in larger Blazor or MAUI apps.Thatâ€™s where EventX comes in â€” a lightweight, thread-safe C# library that brings event-driven architecture to your .NET apps, with zero boilerplate.ğŸ”§ What it does:ğŸ” Publish/subscribe to events across the app (sync & async)ğŸ”’ Strongly-typed and memory-leak safeğŸš« Auto-remove listeners with .Once()âœ… Works in Blazor (Server/WASM), MAUI, WPF, etc.ğŸ“¦ Real-World Use Cases:ğŸ›’ Mini Cart updates in E-commerce appsğŸ”” Toast Notifications triggered globallyğŸ“£ Multi-tab communication (via BroadcastChannel)ğŸ§  Loose coupling between services and UIğŸ•µï¸â€â™‚ï¸ Debugging memory leaks with scoped unsubscriptionHere's the beauty: with EventX, your components donâ€™t need to know who is listening â€” they just fire an event, and magic happens ğŸ’¥Visit the link to know more:https://lnkd.in/dvjefT8Ghashtag#dotnet hashtag#csharp hashtag#blazor hashtag#blazorwasm hashtag#dotnetcore hashtag#eventdrivenarchitecture hashtag#developerexperience hashtag#webdevelopment hashtag#frontenddevelopment hashtag#backenddevelopment hashtag#aspnetcore hashtag#softwarearchitecture hashtag#opensource hashtag#dependencyinjection hashtag#eventdriven hashtag#devtools hashtag#programming hashtag#softwareengineering hashtag#reactivity hashtag#multitab hashtag#browserapi hashtag#broadcastchannel hashtag#scalability hashtag#modulararchitecture hashtag#cleanarchitecture

ğŸ”¹ ASP.NET Core Middleware Pipeline â€“ Part 4: Static Files MiddlewareOnce HTTPS is enforced, the next step in the pipeline is enabling your app to serve static content like images, CSS, JavaScript, and other assets.ğŸ—‚ï¸ What does Static Files Middleware do? It allows your ASP.NET Core app to serve files directly from the wwwroot folder (or any configured directory) without needing any controller logic.ğŸ“¦ UseStaticFiles() This middleware scans for static files and returns them if found, bypassing the rest of the pipeline.app.UseStaticFiles();ğŸ“ For example, if you have:wwwroot/css/site.cssA browser can request it at:https://lnkd.in/dnn8CzJbâš ï¸ Security Tip: By default, only the wwwroot folder is accessible. Avoid serving sensitive files by accidentally exposing other directories.ğŸ§  Best Practice: Place UseStaticFiles() early in the pipeline so static content is returned before more complex processing (like routing or authentication).ğŸš€ Coming up next: Routing Middleware â€” the backbone of request processing.hashtag#ASPNETCore hashtag#Middleware hashtag#DotNet hashtag#StaticFiles hashtag#WebDev hashtag#CSharp hashtag#BackendDevelopment
